case_id: Vikram Johar v. State of Uttar Pradesh (2019) 9 SCC 606
facts: Criminal Appeal No. 755 of 2019 arising out of SLP(Crl.) No. 8824 of 2018.
Appellant (Vikram Johar) challenged the order dated 04.09.2018 passed by the High Court of Judicature at Allahabad.
The High Court dismissed the Application under Section 482 CrPC filed by the appellant.
The application sought quashing of Charge-Sheet No. 1 dated 07.07.2017 arising out of Case Crime No. 0117 of 2017.
Charges were under Sections 420 (Cheating) and 406 (Criminal Breach of Trust) of the Indian Penal Code (IPC).
The case was registered at Police Station Sector 20, Gautam Budh Nagar, Uttar Pradesh.
The dispute originated from an Agreement to Sell dated 19.03.2013 between the appellant (seller) and Respondent No. 2/Complainant (buyer) for a property.
Complainant alleged payment of Rs. 1 crore towards the sale consideration.
Complainant alleged that the appellant failed to execute the sale deed as per the agreement.
Complainant further alleged that the appellant failed to return the amount paid despite demands.
FIR was lodged by Respondent No. 2 on 13.03.2017.
Investigation led to the filing of the charge-sheet under Sections 420 and 406 IPC.
Appellant contended before the High Court and Supreme Court that the dispute was purely civil in nature, arising out of a breach of contract.
Appellant argued that the ingredients of cheating (dishonest intention *ab initio*) and criminal breach of trust (entrustment and misappropriation) were not made out from the FIR/Charge-Sheet.
Supreme Court analyzed whether the allegations, taken at face value, disclosed offenses under Sections 420/406 IPC or if it was primarily a civil dispute.
ipc_sections: Section 406 (Punishment for Criminal Breach of Trust)
Section 420 (Cheating and dishonestly inducing delivery of property)
Section 405 (Criminal Breach of Trust - Definition, discussed)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The appellant induced the complainant to part with Rs. 1 crore with a dishonest intention from the beginning, knowing he would not execute the sale deed, constituting cheating under Section 420 IPC.
precedents: Rajesh Bajaj v. State NCT of Delhi, (1999) 3 SCC 259 (FIR should not be quashed if ingredients of offence prima facie exist)
Medchl Chemicals & Pharma (P) Ltd. v. Biological E. Ltd., (2000) 3 SCC 269 (Distinction between mere breach of contract and cheating; dishonest intention is key)
Kamal Shivaji Pokarnekar v. State of Maharashtra, (2019) 14 SCC 350 (If factual foundation for offence laid in complaint, court should not quash)
elements: Inducement leading to delivery of property (money)
Dishonest intention existing at the time of making the promise/inducement (ab initio)

counter_arguments.loophole: Difficulty in proving dishonest intention *at the inception* of the contract merely from subsequent failure to perform.
supporting_precedents: Hridaya Ranjan Prasad Verma v. State of Bihar, (2000) 4 SCC 168 (Absence of allegation that accused had dishonest intention at time of making promise negates cheating)
Anil Mahajan v. Bhor Industries Ltd., (2005) 10 SCC 228 (Failure to keep up promise subsequently, cannot presume dishonest intention at start)
Uma Shankar Gopalika v. State of Bihar, (2005) 10 SCC 336 (Distinction between breach of contract and cheating is fine but crucial; requires initial dishonest intent)

prosecution_arguments.argument: The appellant was entrusted with Rs. 1 crore for the specific purpose of executing a sale deed, and by failing to do so and not returning the money, he dishonestly misappropriated or converted it for his own use, constituting criminal breach of trust under Section 406 IPC.
precedents: Jaswantrai Manilal Akhaney v. State of Bombay, AIR 1956 SC 575 (Definition of entrustment)
State of Gujarat v. Jaswantlal Nathalal, (1968) 2 SCR 408 (Entrustment requires creation of a trust-like relationship)
R K Dalmia v. Delhi Administration, AIR 1962 SC 1821 (Dishonest misappropriation explained)
elements: Entrustment of property (money) or dominion over property
Dishonest misappropriation or conversion to own use
Violation of any direction of law prescribing the mode of discharge of trust
Violation of any legal contract regarding the discharge of trust

counter_arguments.loophole: In a sale agreement, money paid as consideration often passes ownership to the seller, making 'entrustment' in the S.405 sense inapplicable. Failure to perform the seller's obligation (transfer land) is typically a breach of contract, not misappropriation of the received money.
supporting_precedents: S.W. Palanitkar v. State of Bihar, (2002) 1 SCC 241 (Mere breach of contract cannot give rise to criminal prosecution for CBT unless fraudulent/dishonest intention shown at beginning)
Indian Oil Corpn. v. NEPC India Ltd., (2006) 6 SCC 736 (Dispute purely of civil nature arising from commercial transaction; criminal proceedings abuse of process)
Dalip Kaur v. Jagnar Singh, (2009) 14 SCC 696 (Money advanced towards sale consideration does not automatically amount to entrustment for S.406)

defense_arguments.argument: The dispute is fundamentally civil, stemming from a breach of an Agreement to Sell. The failure to execute the sale deed or return the advance money constitutes a breach of contract, for which civil remedies (specific performance, recovery suit) are appropriate, not criminal prosecution.
edge_cases: Invoking Section 482 CrPC jurisdiction of High Court to prevent abuse of process.
Distinguishing contractual liability from criminal culpability.
precedents: State of Haryana v. Bhajan Lal, 1992 Supp (1) SCC 335 (Guidelines for quashing FIR/complaint, including where allegations do not constitute offence or are manifestly attended with mala fides/abuse of process)
Indian Oil Corpn. v. NEPC India Ltd., (2006) 6 SCC 736 (Civil disputes should not be converted into criminal offences)
G. Sagar Suri v. State of U.P., (2000) 2 SCC 636 (Criminal proceedings should not be used to settle scores or pressurize parties in civil disputes)

defense_arguments.argument: The essential ingredients for Section 420 (dishonest intention *ab initio*) and Section 406 (entrustment and dishonest misappropriation) are not made out from the allegations in the FIR and charge-sheet, even if taken at face value.
edge_cases: Burden of proof in criminal cases lies on prosecution.
Requirement for specific allegations establishing mens rea.
precedents: Hridaya Ranjan Prasad Verma v. State of Bihar, (2000) 4 SCC 168 (Crucial element for S.420 is dishonest intention at the time of inducement)
S.W. Palanitkar v. State of Bihar, (2002) 1 SCC 241 (Necessity of proving dishonest intention for S.406)
Thermax Ltd. v. K.M. Johny, (2011) 13 SCC 412 (High Court's duty under S.482 CrPC to examine if uncontroverted allegations establish the offence)

defense_arguments.argument: The initiation of criminal proceedings is an abuse of process, aimed at coercing the appellant into fulfilling the contract or returning money, effectively using the criminal justice system for debt recovery or contract enforcement.
edge_cases: Mala fide intention of the complainant.
Timing of FIR relative to civil dispute arising.
precedents: Chandran Ratnaswami v. K.C. Palanisamy, (2013) 6 SCC 740 (Courts must guard against criminal proceedings being used for oblique motives)
Murari Lal Gupta v. Gopi Singh, (2006) 2 SCC 670 (Simple breach of contract does not constitute cheating)
V.Y. Jose v. State of Gujarat, (2009) 3 SCC 78 (Need for caution in commercial transaction cases turning criminal)

judgment.outcome: Appeal Allowed. The criminal proceedings initiated against the appellant Vikram Johar, arising out of Case Crime No. 0117 of 2017 for offences under Sections 406 and 420 IPC, were quashed.
reasoning: The Supreme Court found that the allegations in the FIR/Charge-Sheet did not disclose the essential ingredients of the offences of cheating (Section 420) or criminal breach of trust (Section 406).
The Court emphasized the distinction between a mere breach of contract and the criminal offences of cheating and criminal breach of trust.

For cheating (S.420), there was no sufficient allegation or material to suggest that the appellant had a fraudulent or dishonest intention *at the very time of making the promise* (i.e., entering the Agreement to Sell). Subsequent failure to fulfill the promise does not automatically imply initial dishonest intent.

For criminal breach of trust (S.406), the Court observed that the transaction was purely commercial. The money paid was towards sale consideration. The Court likely reasoned that this did not constitute 'entrustment' in the manner required by Section 405 IPC, as the money becomes the seller's property upon payment under the agreement, subject to contractual obligations.
The Court concluded that the dispute was essentially civil in nature, arising out of non-performance of a contract.
Allowing the criminal proceedings to continue would amount to an abuse of the process of court, potentially using criminal law machinery to settle a civil dispute.
The Court reiterated principles laid down in previous judgments regarding the quashing of criminal proceedings under Section 482 CrPC where the dispute is primarily civil.
